HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 2, 1926.

CREDIT WHERE DUE
Surprising as it may seem there was a crowd of more than
one hundred people who heard the debate between Washington
and Lee and Johns Hopkins last Thursday night in the Civil
Engineering Hall. We say that the attendance was surprising;
only a year ago for the same event three people and the judges
constituted the audience.
The debating boom is not to be taken without a grain of
the proverbial salt. The crowd, the program, the entire success
of the event rested upon the shoulders of one man. To him the
Debating Council delegated the arduous job of getting an
audience out to listen to the debaters' shouts. It seems to us
that he performed the task extremely well, and the NEWS-LETTER wants to call the attention of the campus to the fact. Mr.
A. Risley Ensor will now take the curtain calls.

STRAYING FROM THE PATH
As-gad- as it may seem -Hopkins undergraduate activities
are in danger of straying from the path of simon pure amateurism. For years it has been the boast of Hopkins men that
the eligibility rules of the University were so strict that any
man who represented any activity in any way was a bona fide
undergraduate in good academic standing.
Alas, the times have changed. We went to the Musical
Club concert on Friday night all set for the good old college
party. We sat through the 'harmony of the Glee Club, we
cheered for the Banjo Club, we applauded heartily for the
various soloists, we wept tears of delight when Rodgers and
his "Russian Boys" gave their Bolshevist love song. All was
well thus far.
And then came the anti-climax. The Blue Jay Orchestra
was good, unexpectedly excellent, but in their midst sat two
or three men who were not Hopkins students; in fact they
probably had never seen the inside of any college building.
It seems to us that this is straying from the old straight
and narrow eligibility road. Would not an orchestra completely made up of Hopkins men be advisable, for the concerts
of the Musical Club at least, even if the music furnished was
slightly inferior? We think so.

Stage. directioir : The stage shall be made to represent
any college library. Many cads ordering Silence! and Quiet!
are hung on the walls and displayed on the librarian's desk.
At the back of the stage shall be a portrait of an oldish man,
in the Napoleonic attitude, with solemn, stupid countenance,—
the founder of the college, Mr. Ezra Cabbage,—holding in his
hand a diploma from one of the city's best business colleges in
years past. When the curtain rises a few students and the
librarian are on the stage. The librarian is busy snapping
books shut and beating them into their places on the shelves.
She hums a little tune while tramping heavily from shelf to
shelf. The students incessantly scrape their feet on the floor
and beat tattoos on the tables with their pencils.
Enter Prof. Lowde.
Prof L.(to Lib.)—Good morning Miss Jones.
Librarian (coyly tucking in a stray hairpin)—Good morning, Professor, you're looking well this morning, tee, hee, and
young, tee, hee. (Both giggle).
First student (to second student, in stage whisper)—Hasn't
she got an affectionate manner?
•
Second student—I don't think so. ( Students laugh.)
Librarian—Silence!
(Professor glares.)
Prof. L.—Miss Books-Librarian—Miss Books! how funny, tee, hee, fee, hee. (Librarian and Professor laugh loud and long.)
Prof. L.—Miss Books (they laugh again) I brought this
book back—the one I got three months ago—is it late?
Librarian-0, that's all right, only 19 people are waiting
for it, and most of them are students.
(Enter Prof. Noyes. He rudely interrupts the conversation
and asks for a book.)
Prof. L.—That is just the book I was about to ask for.
Prof. N.----Well, you hadn't asked for it, had you?
Prof. L.—I was here first.
Prof. N.—I asked first.
Prof. L.—Yes, but you came in and interrupted me while I
was talking—
Prof.
-You shouldn't be standing here talking . all
morning.
(Enter Visitors—A seedy looking youngish man and two
seedy looking ladies, \youngish or otherwise. They stand awestruck before the portrait of Mr. Ezra Cabbage. The Lib goes
to hunt for the book. The profs. retire to the side of the stage
arguing and shaking fingers in each others' faces.)
First Lady Visitor.—Ain't he grand?
Second Lady Visitor.—Ah-h-h so-noble. First Lady Visitor.—And look! two professors!
Gentleman Visitor.—Having a learned argument!
First Lady Visitor.—I know they're professors because they
look so absent-minded like the new school teacher at the cross

Prof. N.—This is not what I asked for.
Prof. L.—Well, you didn't expect it to be, did you?
(Profs leave stage with Librarian, glaring at her and shaking fingers in her face, followed by Visitors writing vigorously
in their memory books. Students, except one, who remain standing. A dead silence follows for five minutes.)
Student.—Oh, this silence! How awful it is! What can I
do? (Drums on table with fingers, then stops. Silence again.
Except for coughing in the audience. The student sinks desolately into his chair.)
Student.—0 God. I'll go crazy! 0, this silence! Will it
never end? Why can't I have some noise? How horribly still it
all is!
. (Five more m▪ inutes of silence, Student jumps up, running
his fingers wildly through his hair.)
Student.—I can't stand it. Quiet! Solitude! I can't stand
it. These solemn, silent books, these unresounding tables and
empty chairs. ... No! No! No! I won't, I can't. (Takes from
hiS pocket a pistol, which he carries for classroom hand shakers,
and meditates, looking at it fondly.)
Student—At least, this ghastly stillness will be shattered
for a moment ere I die.
(Shoots and falls dead)
Curtain.

HOPKINS DEBATING TEAM
LOSES TO W. AND L.

3

(Continued from p. 1, col. 3)

Donald Niles now took the.platform for Hopkins, giving the economic reasons in favor of recognition. First, Russia is economically stable, he explained. -Eco'nomically, which is to say basically, a country's foundations are
built upon the economic bonds that
it it-self weaves."
Niles introduced his second
point with There is a vast field
in Russia for investment of American capital and the United States
needs a foreign field in which to
invest capital." The Hopkins debater showed that recognition
would open new- fields for commercial prosperity. After proving
that the Russian exports to the
-United States have been increasing; Niles cleverly stated, -A
healthy organism grows under bad
conditions,,but that does not justify bad conditions."
Visitor Gives Challenge

Charles W. Lowry,. Jr. spoke
next for the negative. In a welltoned voice, the Washington and
Lee debater showed that Russia
has not fulfilled the requisites necessary to recognition of a de jure
government. "I challenge my opponents to show an actual repudiation of Communist principles
since 1918."
Lowry continued, -The United
States is morally bound to refuse
recognition, because the Soviet
government is a minority government. * * Human life is a 'cheap
commodity in Russia. * * Those
who deny freedom to others do
not deserve it themselves."
The rebuttals were spirited and
it was here that the Hopkins debaters excelled. If their main
speeches had equalled their rebuttals, it is believed that the decision would have gone to Hopkins.
An unusual feature- of the debate was the presence of a number of Russians who showed intense interest in the discussion.
The judges were Dr.. Wilbur
Smith, Dr. C. T. Heatwole, and
Mr. E. J. Rutt. Dr. John C.
French presided.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 2, 1926..

Worlds Records Crash
In Annual Indoor Games
Through the smoky atmosphere
of the Fifth Regiment Armory, in
the midst of almost absolute silence, Charles Hoff soared high in
the blue mist which billowed up
from numerous photographical
flashes, to shatter' again his own
world's record for the pole vault.
With the horizontal bar placed at
13 feet 51/
8 inches, the Norwegian
catapulted from the floor and upon
reaching the level of the bar snapped himself over six inches above
the standards to land in the saw
dust pile with a new world's record in his grasp.
Later on in the evening he ran
the 440 with three others and continued on in an effort to break the
500-yard run world's record. He
ran a pretty race, but he missed
the objective by two-thirds of a
record.
The 1926 games witnessed .two
broken world's records and one
tied record. Cummings of Virginia, who pushed Louis Clarke
into establishing the indoor dash
record of 9 4-5 seconds two years
ago, again took second place in the
dash won by Hussey in the same
time.
Boston College won handily
from Penn State in Distance Medley relay. Penn began with the

CALENDAR

CutYour Costs

lead but lost it early in the event
never to regain it again. The Civitan trophy went to the winner.
Georgetown unfortunately withdrew from the race.
The games this year were tilled
with all that has heretofore been
Records were
characteristic.
smashed, the stars did all that was
expected of them, -the high school
material looked splendid.
Outstanding among the scholastics was Penniman of Gilman, who
finished second .to Hoff in the International Invitation 440. To do
this the high school lad had to
consign Pugh of Maryland to third
place and relegate the Richmond
College entry, who ran second the
greater part of the race, to an
ignonimous fourth.
The meet was crammed full of
thrilling incidents from start to
finish. Johns Hopkins, although
it did not exactly cover itself
with glory, had a good cause to
be proud of. Prospects look
bright for the coming• outdoor
season. Heyn, Pindell, and Armstrong placed in the 60-yard
S. A. A. A. U. dash which Heyn
won. Severance placed in the 440
and the relays did well in both
events in which: they were entered.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 2, 1926.

CREDIT WHERE DUE
Surprising as it may seem there was a crowd of more than
one hundred people who heard the debate between Washington
and Lee and Johns Hopkins last Thursday night in the Civil
Engineering Hall. We say that the attendance was surprising;
only a year ago for the same event three people and the judges
constituted the audience.
The debating boom is not to be taken without a grain of
the proverbial salt. The crowd, the program, the entire success
of the event rested upon the shoulders of one man. To him the
Debating Council delegated the arduous job of getting an
audience out to listen to the debaters' shouts. It seems to us
that he performed the task extremely well, and the NEWS-LETTER wants to call the attention of the campus to the fact. Mr.
A. Risley Ensor will now take the curtain calls.

STRAYING FROM THE PATH
As-gad- as it may seem -Hopkins undergraduate activities
are in danger of straying from the path of simon pure amateurism. For years it has been the boast of Hopkins men that
the eligibility rules of the University were so strict that any
man who represented any activity in any way was a bona fide
undergraduate in good academic standing.
Alas, the times have changed. We went to the Musical
Club concert on Friday night all set for the good old college
party. We sat through the 'harmony of the Glee Club, we
cheered for the Banjo Club, we applauded heartily for the
various soloists, we wept tears of delight when Rodgers and
his "Russian Boys" gave their Bolshevist love song. All was
well thus far.
And then came the anti-climax. The Blue Jay Orchestra
was good, unexpectedly excellent, but in their midst sat two
or three men who were not Hopkins students; in fact they
probably had never seen the inside of any college building.
It seems to us that this is straying from the old straight
and narrow eligibility road. Would not an orchestra completely made up of Hopkins men be advisable, for the concerts
of the Musical Club at least, even if the music furnished was
slightly inferior? We think so.

Characters:

Students.

Stage. directioir : The stage shall be made to represent
any college library. Many cads ordering Silence! and Quiet!
are hung on the walls and displayed on the librarian's desk.
At the back of the stage shall be a portrait of an oldish man,
in the Napoleonic attitude, with solemn, stupid countenance,—
the founder of the college, Mr. Ezra Cabbage,—holding in his
hand a diploma from one of the city's best business colleges in
years past. When the curtain rises a few students and the
librarian are on the stage. The librarian is busy snapping
books shut and beating them into their places on the shelves.
She hums a little tune while tramping heavily from shelf to
shelf. The students incessantly scrape their feet on the floor
and beat tattoos on the tables with their pencils.
Enter Prof. Lowde.
Prof L.(to Lib.)—Good morning Miss Jones.
Librarian (coyly tucking in a stray hairpin)—Good morning, Professor, you're looking well this morning, tee, hee, and
young, tee, hee. (Both giggle).
First student (to second student, in stage whisper)—Hasn't
she got an affectionate manner?
•
Second student—I don't think so. ( Students laugh.)
Librarian—Silence!
(Professor glares.)
Prof. L.—Miss Books-Librarian—Miss Books! how funny, tee, hee, fee, hee. (Librarian and Professor laugh loud and long.)
Prof. L.—Miss Books (they laugh again) I brought this
book back—the one I got three months ago—is it late?
Librarian-0, that's all right, only 19 people are waiting
for it, and most of them are students.
(Enter Prof. Noyes. He rudely interrupts the conversation
and asks for a book.)
Prof. L.—That is just the book I was about to ask for.
Prof. N.----Well, you hadn't asked for it, had you?
Prof. L.—I was here first.
Prof. N.—I asked first.
Prof. L.—Yes, but you came in and interrupted me while I
was talking—
Prof.
-You shouldn't be standing here talking . all
morning.
(Enter Visitors—A seedy looking youngish man and two
seedy looking ladies, \youngish or otherwise. They stand awestruck before the portrait of Mr. Ezra Cabbage. The Lib goes
to hunt for the book. The profs. retire to the side of the stage
arguing and shaking fingers in each others' faces.)
First Lady Visitor.—Ain't he grand?
Second Lady Visitor.—Ah-h-h so-noble. First Lady Visitor.—And look! two professors!
Gentleman Visitor.—Having a learned argument!
First Lady Visitor.—I know they're professors because they
look so absent-minded like the new school teacher at the cross
roads only, they look bookier.
'
returns with book, giving it to professors.)
(Librarian
Prof. N.—This is not what I asked for.
Prof. L.—Well, you didn't expect it to be, did you?
(Profs leave stage with Librarian, glaring at her and shaking fingers in her face, followed by Visitors writing vigorously
in their memory books. Students, except one, who remain standing. A dead silence follows for five minutes.)
Student.—Oh, this silence! How awful it is! What can I
do? (Drums on table with fingers, then stops. Silence again.
Except for coughing in the audience. The student sinks desolately into his chair.)
Student.—0 God. I'll go crazy! 0, this silence! Will it
never end? Why can't I have some noise? How horribly still it
all is!
. (Five more m▪ inutes of silence, Student jumps up, running
his fingers wildly through his hair.)
Student.—I can't stand it. Quiet! Solitude! I can't stand
it. These solemn, silent books, these unresounding tables and
empty chairs. ... No! No! No! I won't, I can't. (Takes from
hiS pocket a pistol, which he carries for classroom hand shakers,
and meditates, looking at it fondly.)
Student—At least, this ghastly stillness will be shattered
for a moment ere I die.
(Shoots and falls dead)
Curtain.

Donald Niles now took the.platform for Hopkins, giving the economic reasons in favor of recognition. First, Russia is economically stable, he explained. -Eco'nomically, which is to say basically, a country's foundations are
built upon the economic bonds that
it it-self weaves."
Niles introduced his second
point with There is a vast field
in Russia for investment of American capital and the United States
needs a foreign field in which to
invest capital." The Hopkins debater showed that recognition
would open new- fields for commercial prosperity. After proving
that the Russian exports to the
-United States have been increasing; Niles cleverly stated, -A
healthy organism grows under bad
conditions,,but that does not justify bad conditions."
Visitor Gives Challenge

Charles W. Lowry,. Jr. spoke
next for the negative. In a welltoned voice, the Washington and
Lee debater showed that Russia
has not fulfilled the requisites necessary to recognition of a de jure
government. "I challenge my opponents to show an actual repudiation of Communist principles
since 1918."
Lowry continued, -The United
States is morally bound to refuse
recognition, because the Soviet
government is a minority government. * * Human life is a 'cheap
commodity in Russia. * * Those
who deny freedom to others do
not deserve it themselves."
The rebuttals were spirited and
it was here that the Hopkins debaters excelled. If their main
speeches had equalled their rebuttals, it is believed that the decision would have gone to Hopkins.
An unusual feature- of the debate was the presence of a number of Russians who showed intense interest in the discussion.
The judges were Dr.. Wilbur
Smith, Dr. C. T. Heatwole, and
Mr. E. J. Rutt. Dr. John C.
French presided.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 2, 1926..

Worlds Records Crash
In Annual Indoor Games
Through the smoky atmosphere
of the Fifth Regiment Armory, in
the midst of almost absolute silence, Charles Hoff soared high in
the blue mist which billowed up
from numerous photographical
flashes, to shatter' again his own
world's record for the pole vault.
With the horizontal bar placed at
13 feet 51/
8 inches, the Norwegian
catapulted from the floor and upon
reaching the level of the bar snapped himself over six inches above
the standards to land in the saw
dust pile with a new world's record in his grasp.
Later on in the evening he ran
the 440 with three others and continued on in an effort to break the
500-yard run world's record. He
ran a pretty race, but he missed
the objective by two-thirds of a
record.
The 1926 games witnessed .two
broken world's records and one
tied record. Cummings of Virginia, who pushed Louis Clarke
into establishing the indoor dash
record of 9 4-5 seconds two years
ago, again took second place in the
dash won by Hussey in the same
time.
Boston College won handily
from Penn State in Distance Medley relay. Penn began with the

CALENDAR

lead but lost it early in the event
never to regain it again. The Civitan trophy went to the winner.
Georgetown unfortunately withdrew from the race.
The games this year were tilled
with all that has heretofore been
Records were
characteristic.
smashed, the stars did all that was
expected of them, -the high school
material looked splendid.
Outstanding among the scholastics was Penniman of Gilman, who
finished second .to Hoff in the International Invitation 440. To do
this the high school lad had to
consign Pugh of Maryland to third
place and relegate the Richmond
College entry, who ran second the
greater part of the race, to an
ignonimous fourth.
The meet was crammed full of
thrilling incidents from start to
finish. Johns Hopkins, although
it did not exactly cover itself
with glory, had a good cause to
be proud of. Prospects look
bright for the coming• outdoor
season. Heyn, Pindell, and Armstrong placed in the 60-yard
S. A. A. A. U. dash which Heyn
won. Severance placed in the 440
and the relays did well in both
events in which: they were entered.
